feed.title: Current watches, warnings, and advisories for United States land zones

entry.title: Flood Advisory issued September 2 at 4:30PM CDT until September 2 at 7:30PM CDT by NWS San Angelo TX
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Urban and small stream flooding caused by excessive rainfall is expected.
* WHERE...Northern Tom Green and northwestern Concho counties west central Texas.
* WHEN...Until 730 PM CDT.
* IMPACTS...Minor flooding in low-lying and poor drainage areas. Rises in small streams and normally dry arroyos. Water over roadways.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 426 PM CDT, Doppler radar indicated heavy rain of 1 to 2 inches due to thunderstorms. This will cause urban and small stream flooding. - Some locations that will experience flooding include... San Angelo, Paint Rock, Goodfellow Air Force Base, Wall, Veribest, O.C. Fisher Reservoir, San Angelo State Park, Orient, Grape Creek, Vancourt, Mereta, Carlsbad, Tankersley, Eola, Lowake, Knickerbocker, Water Valley and Harriet. Low water crossings in northern Tom Green and northwestern Concho County will be affected by this heavy rainfall. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood
entry.cap:areaDesc: Concho, TX; Tom Green, TX

cap:parameter.value: FLOOD ADVISORY IN EFFECT UNTIL 730 PM CDT THIS EVENING

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued September 2 at 5:28PM EDT by NWS Jacksonville FL
entry.summary:

HAZARD...Wind gusts around 40 mph and minor flooding due to heavy rainfall.

IMPACT...Gusty winds could knock down tree limbs and blow around unsecured objects. Minor flooding due to heavy rainfall is possible.
Locations impacted include... Palm Coast, Bunnell, Andalusia, Marineland, Crescent Beach, Beverly Beach, and Espanola.

entry.title: Flash Flood Warning issued September 2 at 4:19PM CDT until September 2 at 7:30PM CDT by NWS Midland/Odessa TX
entry.summary:
FFWMAF
The National Weather Service in Midland/Odessa has issued a
* Flash Flood Warning for... Southern Reagan County in western Texas... East Central Upton County in western Texas...
* Until 730 PM CDT.
* At 419 PM CDT, Doppler radar indicated thunderstorms producing heavy rain across the warned area. The expected rainfall rate is 2 to 3 inches in 1 hour. Flash flooding is ongoing or expected to begin shortly.
HAZARD...Flash flooding caused by thunderstorms.
SOURCE...Radar.
IMPACT...Flash flooding of small creeks and streams, urban areas, highways, streets and underpasses as well as other poor drainage and low-lying areas.
* Some locations that will experience flash flooding include... Big Lake, Reagan County Airport and Best.
This includes the following streams and drainages... High Lonesome Draw, Isaac Draw, Schneemann Draw, Rankin Draw, Big Jim Draw, Live Oak Creek and Centralia Draw.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Reagan, TX; Upton, TX

entry.title: Flash Flood Warning issued September 2 at 4:04PM CDT until September 2 at 5:30PM CDT by NWS Midland/Odessa TX
entry.summary:
At 404 PM CDT, Doppler radar indicated thunderstorms producing heavy rain across the warned area. Between 4 and 5 inches of rain have fallen just northwest of Odessa. Flash flooding is ongoing. Although rain rates have diminished, any extra rainfall will only exacerbate flooding already occurring.
HAZARD...Life threatening flash flooding. Thunderstorms producing flash flooding.
SOURCE...Radar.
IMPACT...Life threatening flash flooding of creeks and streams, urban areas, highways, streets and underpasses.
Some locations that will experience flash flooding include... Midland, Odessa, Goldsmith, West Odessa, Midland International Air and Space Port, Odessa Schlemeyer Field, Warfield, Penwell, Midland Airpark, Skywest Airport, Cotton Flat and Notrees.
This includes the following streams and drainages... Mustang Draw, Johnson Draw, Monahans Draw and Midland Draw.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Ector, TX; Midland, TX

entry.title: Red Flag Warning issued September 2 at 2:04PM PDT until September 2 at 8:00PM PDT by NWS Medford OR
entry.summary:
* IMPACTS...Strong winds combined with critically low relative humidity could lead to the rapid growth and spread of new and existing fires. Outdoor burning is banned during fire season.
* AFFECTED AREA...In California, most of Fire Weather Zone (FWZ) 285 including the Modoc National Forest. In Oregon, southeast portion of FWZ 624 and much of FWZ 625. This includes the eastern portions of the Fremont Winema National Forest and areas south of Silver Lake.
* WIND...Southwest 20 to 30 mph with gusts to 40 mph. Winds become west late in the afternoon.
* HUMIDITY...9 to 14 percent.
* DETAILED URL...View the hazard area in detail at https://www.wrh.noaa.gov/map/?wfo=mfr
entry.cap:areaDesc: Modoc County Except for the Surprise Valley; Klamath Basin and the Fremont-Winema National Forest; South Central Oregon Desert including the BLM Land in Eastern Lake and Western Harney Counties

entry.title: Flash Flood Warning issued September 2 at 4:50PM AST until September 2 at 7:00PM AST by NWS San Juan PR
entry.summary:
At 450 PM AST, Doppler radar indicated thunderstorms producing heavy rain across the warned area. Between 1 and 3 inches of rain have fallen. Additional rainfall amounts of 0.5 to 1 inch are possible in the warned area. Flash flooding is ongoing or expected to begin shortly.
HAZARD...Life threatening flash flooding. Thunderstorms producing flash flooding.

IMPACT...Life threatening flash flooding of creeks and streams, urban areas, highways, streets and underpasses.

entry.title: Red Flag Warning issued September 2 at 2:22PM MDT until September 2 at 9:00PM MDT by NWS Boise ID
entry.summary:
...RED FLAG WARNING IN EFFECT FROM 9 AM MDT /8 AM PDT/ TODAY TO MIDNIGHT MDT /11 PM PDT/ MONDAY NIGHT FOR LIGHTNING FOR FIRE WEATHER ZONES 400, 401, 402, 403, 420, 421, 423, 424, 426, AND 646...
...RED FLAG WARNING IN EFFECT FROM 9 AM MDT /8 AM PDT/ TO 9 PM MDT /8 PM PDT/ TODAY FOR LIGHTNING AND WINDS/RH FOR FIRE WEATHER ZONES 636 AND 637...
.The much-anticipated afternoon round of thunderstorms is developing and storms will continue to move northeast. Scattered lightning and wind gusts to 60 mph are expected. In addition, strong winds and low RH has developed across southern Burns and Vale BLM this afternoon. No changes were made to the warning this afternoon. Storms may continue past midnight across the northern part of the area, generally from Baker Valley east through the Payette and Northern Boise NF, and although unlikely, the warning may need to be extended in that area.
* Thunderstorms...Scattered.
* Outflow Winds...Gusts 40-60 mph.
* Timing...Until 9 PM MDT /8 PM PDT/ this evening.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Burns BLM; Vale BLM

entry.title: Red Flag Warning issued September 2 at 2:08PM MDT until September 2 at 8:00PM MDT by NWS Rapid City SD
entry.summary:
...RED FLAG WARNING FOR MUCH OF THE WESTERN SD PLAINS THROUGH TUESDAY EVENING...
...RED FLAG WARNING FOR MUCH OF THE NORTHEASTERN WY PLAINS THROUGH THIS EVENING...
.Critical fire weather conditions are expected today through tomorrow for much of the area.
Today, critical fire weather conditions are ongoing over portions of northeastern Wyoming and much of western South Dakota. Temperatures in the 90s, relative humidity values in the single digits to lower teens, and sustained south to southwest winds of 15 to 25 mph with gusts as high as 35 mph have been observed over the last few hours. This includes portions of the northeastern Wyoming plains not previously in a Red Flag Warning. Winds are still expected to decrease in some of these locations this afternoon, particularly western Crook County; however, critical fire weather conditions will likely continue in the near term, especially in the vicinity of any virga or showers that may lead to locally enhanced wind gusts.
Tonight, winds will decrease from west to east, with winds expected to fall below criteria across northeastern Wyoming. Over western and central South Dakota, a developing low-level jet should allow breezy and gusty winds to continue, along with limiting relative humidity recovery. Although critical fire weather conditions may briefly subside, very dry and gusty conditions should persist, particularly from southwestern to south central South Dakota. As such, the Red Flag Warning for western South Dakota continues through tomorrow evening.
The National Weather Service in Rapid City has issued a Red Flag Warning for gusty winds and low relative humidity, which is in effect until 8 PM MDT this evening.
* AFFECTED AREA...Fire Weather Zones 315 Southern Campbell, 316 Crook County Plains and 317 Weston County Plains.
* WINDS...West to southwest 10 to 20 mph with gusts to 30 mph.
* RELATIVE HUMIDITY...As low as 9 percent.
* IMPACTS...The combination of gusty winds and low relative humidity will produce critical fire weather conditions.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Southern Campbell; Crook County Plains; Weston County Plains

cap:parameter.value: RED FLAG WARNING IN EFFECT UNTIL 8 PM MDT THIS EVENING FOR GUSTY WINDS AND LOW RELATIVE HUMIDITY FOR FIRE WEATHER ZONES 315, 316, AND 317

entry.title: Flood Warning issued September 2 at 3:06PM CDT until September 3 at 4:32PM CDT by NWS Midland/Odessa TX
entry.summary:
...The Flood Warning continues for the following rivers in Texas...
Rio Grande at Rio Grande at Johnson Ranch near Castolon, Texas affecting Brewster County.
For the Rio Grande...including Rio Grande at Johnson Ranch near Castolon, Texas...Minor flooding is forecast.
* WHAT...Minor flooding is forecast.
* WHERE...Rio Grande at Rio Grande at Johnson Ranch near Castolon, Texas.
* WHEN...From this evening to tomorrow afternoon.
* IMPACTS...At 12.0 feet (3.7 meters), the river reaches bankfull, minor lowland flooding occurs, and no significant damage is expected. At 15.0 feet (4.6 meters), flood stage is reached. Moderate lowland flooding begins. Roads that lead to Cottonwood Campground and River Road may flood. Stages are practically synonymous with the gage at Cottonwood Campground at Castolon (CSTT2), and therefore represent the reach from Santa Elena Canyon through Cottonwood Campground, where damage may occur. Cattle also graze in the lowlands, and may be threatened.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 2:15 PM CDT Monday the stage was 11.1 feet (3.4 meters). - Bankfull stage is 12.0 feet (3.7 meters). - Forecast...The river is expected to rise above flood stage this evening to a crest of 15.7 feet (4.8 meters) just after midnight tonight. It will then fall below flood stage late tonight. - Flood stage is 15.0 feet (4.6 meters). - Flood History...This crest compares to a previous crest of 15.7 feet (4.8 meters) on 07/23/2024. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood
entry.cap:areaDesc: Brewster, TX

cap:parameter.value: FLOOD WARNING NOW IN EFFECT FROM THIS EVENING TO TOMORROW AFTERNOON

entry.title: Air Quality Alert issued September 2 at 2:00PM MDT by NWS Great Falls MT
entry.summary:
AQAMT
The Montana Department of Environmental Quality has issued an air quality alert for Beaverhead, Deer Lodge, Granite, Lake, Mineral, Missoula, Ravalli, Sanders, and Silver Bow counties in effect until 4 PM 9/3/2024 elevated particulate levels from wildfire smoke This alert will be updated again at 4 PM 9/3/2024.
An Air Quality Alert means that particulates have been trending upwards and that an exceedence of the 24 hour National Ambient Air Quality Standard (NAAQS) has occurred or may occur in the near future.
As of 2 PM Monday, Particulate levels in Hamilton are Very Unhealthy
As of 2 PM Monday, Particulate levels in Butte and Missoula are Unhealthy for Sensitive Groups
As of 2 PM Monday, Particulate levels in Dillon, Frenchtown, Seeley Lake are Moderate
When air quality is Very Unhealthy... State and local health officials recommend that people with respiratory or heart disease, the elderly, and children should avoid any outdoor activity; everyone else should avoid prolonged exertion.
When air quality is Unhealthy for Sensitive Groups... State and local health officials recommend that people with respiratory or heart disease, the elderly and children should limit prolonged exertion.
When air quality is Moderate... State and local health officials recommend that unusually sensitive people should consider reducing prolonged or heavy exertion.
For more information visit the Montana Department of Environmental Quality at http://todaysair.mtdeq.us
entry.cap:areaDesc: Beaverhead, MT; Deer Lodge, MT; Granite, MT; Lake, MT; Mineral, MT; Missoula, MT; Ravalli, MT; Sanders, MT; Silver Bow, MT

entry.title: Air Quality Alert issued September 2 at 11:09AM CDT by NWS Duluth MN
entry.summary:
* WHAT...The Minnesota Pollution Control Agency has issued an Air Quality Alert for fine particles pollution. The Air Quality Index (AQI) is expected to reach the Red or Unhealthy category.
* WHERE...North central and northwest Minnesota. Including the tribal nations of Leech Lake, Mille Lacs, and Red Lake.
* WHEN...Until 1 AM CDT Tuesday.
* IMPACTS...Some members of the general public may experience health effects. Sensitive groups, such as people with lung disease (including asthma), heart disease, and children and older adults, may experience health effects.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...Smoke from numerous wildfires across the Saskatchewan province in Canada has been pulled into portions of northern and central Minnesota by northerly winds. High pressure will move into the region and will produce very light winds on Monday. This airmass has become stagnant and heavy ground-level smoke will linger across the northern half of the state for the remainder of the day on Monday. Air quality is expected reach the Red (Unhealthy) AQI category across north central Minnesota. Air quality will reach the Orange (Unhealthy for Sensitive Groups) AQI category for the remainder of the alert area. Winds will become southerly Monday afternoon, and will begin to push the smoke back to the north. Dispersion will improve and smoke levels will gradually decrease beginning in the afternoon. Smoke levels should drop below alert levels by 1 AM Tuesday.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Koochiching; North Itasca; North Cass; South Itasca; South Cass; Crow Wing; Northern Aitkin; South Aitkin

cap:parameter.value: AIR QUALITY ALERT IN EFFECT UNTIL 1 AM CDT TUESDAY

entry.title: Flood Warning issued September 2 at 9:55AM EDT until September 6 at 8:00PM EDT by NWS Jacksonville FL
entry.summary:
...The Flood Warning continues for the following rivers in Florida...
Santa Fe River At Three Rivers Estates affecting Suwannee, Gilchrist and Columbia Counties.
Additional information is available at https://water.weather.gov/wfo/JAX
* WHAT...Minor flooding is occurring and minor flooding is forecast.
* WHERE...Santa Fe River at Three Rivers Estates.
* WHEN...Until Friday evening.
* IMPACTS...At 16.0 feet, Lowland flooding begins on SW Santa Fe Drive south of Santa Fe Road in Columbia County. At 16.3 feet, Florida Fish and Wildlife Commission begins enforcement of a no wake zone on the Santa Fe River from the unnamed island 1.5 miles downstream of the Wilson's Spring Boat Ramp to the confluence with the Suwannee River and on the Ichetucknee River upstream to the US 27 bridge. At 17.0 feet, Water begins to enter backyards of residences on Santa Fe Road in Columbia County and on River Run Road in Suwannee County. At 18.0 feet, Water begins to flood River Run Road in Suwannee County. At 18.8 feet, Florida Fish and Wildlife Commission expands the no wake zone restriction further upstream on the Santa Fe River from the unnamed island 1.5 miles downstream on the Wilson's Spring Boat Ramp to one-half mile upstream of the State Road 47 bridge. At 19.0 feet, Water begins to enter backyards of residences along the Ichetucknee River. At 19.8 feet, Waters begins to affect homes in the Hollingsworth Bluff area at State Route 47. At 20.0 feet, Access to homes on Santa Fe Road below SW Riverside Avenue becomes restricted in Columbia. Flooding begins on Santa Fe and Wilson Springs Road.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 9:00 AM EDT Monday the stage was 18.3 feet. - Forecast...The river is expected to fall below flood stage early Friday afternoon and continue falling to 16.1 feet Monday, September 09. - Flood stage is 17.0 feet. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood
entry.cap:areaDesc: Columbia, FL; Gilchrist, FL; Suwannee, FL

entry.title: Air Quality Alert issued September 2 at 6:15AM MDT by NWS Great Falls MT
entry.summary:
AQAMT
The Montana Department of Environmental Quality has issued an air quality alert for Beaverhead, Deer Lodge, Granite, Lake, Mineral, Missoula, Ravalli, Sanders, and Silver Bow counties in effect until 4 PM 9/2/2024 elevated particulate levels from wildfire smoke. This alert will be updated again at 400 PM 9/2/2024.
An Air Quality Alert means that particulates have been trending upwards and that an exceedence of the 24 hour National Ambient Air Quality Standard (NAAQS) has occurred or may occur in the near future.
As of 2 PM Sunday, Particulate levels in Hamilton are Unhealthy
As of 2 PM Sunday, Particulate levels in Butte, Dillon, Missoula are Moderate
When air quality is Unhealthy... State and local health officials recommend that people with respiratory or heart disease, the elderly, and children should avoid prolonged exertion; everyone else should limit prolonged exertion.
When air quality is Moderate... State and local health officials recommend that unusually sensitive people should consider reducing prolonged or heavy exertion.
For more information visit the Montana Department of Environmental Quality at http://todaysair.mtdeq.us
entry.cap:areaDesc: Beaverhead, MT; Deer Lodge, MT; Granite, MT; Lake, MT; Mineral, MT; Missoula, MT; Ravalli, MT; Sanders, MT; Silver Bow, MT

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued September 1 at 2:27PM AKDT by NWS Fairbanks AK
entry.summary:
A low pressure system in Siberia will bring a front to the Chukchi Sea Coast providing gusty winds and elevated water. The strongest south/southwest winds will be approaching gale force with gusts up to 55 mph near Point Hope and Cape Lisburne. Sea levels on south/west facing shorelines look to rise about 1 to 2 feet on Wednesday, then recede to normal levels on Thursday.
Stay tuned to the latest forecast updates at www.weather.gov/afg
entry.cap:areaDesc: Western Arctic Coast; Northwest Arctic Coast
